Detailed Description

Module Root File System (RFS) is APOXI's API layer which provides unified file and directory access to data stored on any kind of storage device.

Purpose and design goals

  • Unified file and directory access on any storage device available on the mobile station
  • Locate files and directories via paths
  • Provide iterators to easily traverse the files of a directory
  • Allow filtering of files while traversing
  • Support visitor pattern to be prepared for future needs
  • Unicode interface for internationalization
  • Support for plug & play storage devices
  • Save with respect to memory leaks
  • Extensible for new storage devices without any change in existing code

Concepts

  • Central controller
    • class RootFileSystem (only static members)
  • Storage devices
    • abstract class StorageDevice
  • Paths, pathnames, and persistable path profiles
    • classes Path, Pathname, and PathProfile
  • Files and directories
    • abstract class File
  • Directory iterators with file filters
    • abstract class DirectoryIterator and class FileFilter
  • Storage device iterators with storage device filters
    • classes StorageDeviceIterator and StorageDeviceFilter
  • File visitors
    • abstract class FileVisitor
  • Storage device visitors
    • abstract class StorageDeviceVisitor

Class hierarchy overview

The following four images give an overview of the root file system's class hierarchy. Please notice the following meaning of colors and line styles:
  • line styles
    • solid boxes: existing classes
    • dashed boxes: possible extensions
  • colors
    • yellow: classes which are used by clients of the RFS
      • strong yellow: concrete classes
      • light yellow: abstract classes
    • blue: classes which are not used by the clients of the RFS, these are pure implementation classes

How to add storage devices

As already stated the root file system is designed to be easily extended for new storage devices. Actually, to add support for a new storage device the APOXI code doesn't have to be changed at all. This section gives an overview on what to do in general to add support for a new storage device to the root file system.

To integrate a new storage device into the root file system the following basic steps have to be done:

  • find a unique short name for the storage device,
  • implement the three classes StorageDevice, File, and DirectoryIterator, and
  • register the storage device at a proper moment to the root file system.

Storage device short name

Storage devices are identified by a short name which is at most three significant characters in length. E.g., the flash storage device is identified by short name ffs and the virtual root storage device is identified by short name rfs.

It is a basic requirement of the root file system that each storage device has its unique short name for proper functionality. If not, the storage devices having the same name can't be registered to the root file system at the same time. Registering is handled with first-come-first-served policy, the first storage device with a short name not yet registered is registered successfully but registering the second one with the same name will fail.

If, for example, you would like to add a USB storage device to the root file system then usb would be a proper short name since it is not used yet and really a good mnemonic for this kind of storage device.

Write implementation classes

As you can see in the core classes hierarchy chart above there exist the three abstract classes
  • StorageDevice,
  • File, and
  • DirectoryIterator.

For integrating a new storage device into the root file system you have to implement these three classes according to the specifics of the new storage device. The documentation of these three abstract base classes provides detailed information on how to derive implementation classes thereof. There are naming conventions for storage device implementation classes, they are described there, too.

The absolute minimum is to implement the pure virtual methods, however, many other methods are declared virtual to allow overriding them in case, too. The methods of the derived class have to interact with the very basic storage device driver API which is provided for the storage device hardware.

For example, the flash storage device is integrated to the root file system with only the classes

  • FlashStorageDeviceImp,
  • FlashFileImp, and
  • FlashDirectoryIteratorImp.

These three classes also serve as an example and reference for how to properly integrate some storage device into the root file system.

There is another storage device implemented already, the root storage device, which is actually a virtual storage device that provides a virtual root directory / and holds all currently registered storage devices as its subdirectories. The subdirectories of the root are to be interpreted as device directories and have the short name of the respective storage device. The root storage device is implemented using the classes

  • RootStorageDeviceImp,
  • RootFileImp, and
  • RootDirectoryIteratorImp.

In the core classes hierarchy chart above there are also drawn in dashed lines the classes

  • UsbStorageDeviceImp,
  • UsbFileImp, and
  • UsbDirectoryIteratorImp.

These classes don't exist yet, but they show where a new USB storage device would be hooked into the root file system framework.

Register the storage device

Before a storage device can be accessed via the root file system it has to be registered to it. So the last step for integrating a storage device into the root file system is the registration of it to the root file system at runtime. By registration the storage device gets hooked into the root file system framework and from then on is accessible via its storage device short name until it gets unregistered again. We have to distinguish two kinds of storage devices which influence the time of registration:
  • permanent storage devices and
  • plug & play storage devices.

Registering permanent storage devices

Permanent storage devices are always available to the mobile station, they are built-in devices which can't be removed. Permanent storage devices shall be registered at system startup. Some proper code location has to be found where to do that.

Registering plug & play storage devices

Plug & play storage devices can be added to the system and removed from the system at runtime. This means whenever a storage device is plugged in then it has to be registered to the root file system and as soon as it gets plugged out it has to be deregistered from the root file system.

Define Documentation

#define APOXI_MAX_NET_FILENAME_LENGTH   255
 

Defines the maximal length of a filename supported by the RFS. This length does not include the space for the terminating 0 character. The define defaults to 255 (complying with the MS FAT32 File System Specification), however, it can be overridden on compile time via an overriding command line define.

#define APOXI_MAX_NET_STORAGE_DEVICE_ID_LENGTH   3
 

Defines the maximal length of a storage device Id string supported by the RFS. This length does not include the space for the terminating 0 character. The define defaults to 3, however, it can be overridden on compile time via an overriding command line define.

#define APOXI_MAX_PATHNAME_LENGTH
 

Value:

(                             \
        1 /* The starting separator. */ +                           \
        APOXI_MAX_NET_FILENAME_LENGTH + /* The filename itself. */  \
        1 /* The terminating \c 0 character. */                     \
        )
Defines the maximal pathname length including the terminating 0 character.
